Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story:
I wiped the sweat from my brow as the foreman signaled the end of our shift. As a construction laborer, I knew the drill: sweep up my area, make sure every nail and scrap was cleared, and leave the site spotless and safe. But today, my mind was split. Just this morning, at the volunteer center, the coordinator had emphasized new safety steps—no shortcuts, no exceptions. She’d made it clear: follow the updated guidelines, even if it meant slowing down.

Now, standing in the half-lit site, I glanced at the clock. If I stuck to the usual quick sweep, I’d finish on time and keep the crew happy. But the volunteer coordinator’s words echoed in my head. The new steps would take longer, and I’d risk being late for my next shift. My coworkers expected me to keep pace, not hold them up. But as a volunteer, I was supposed to set an example, even here. My hands tightened around the broom. I could feel the pressure mounting from both sides, each demanding something different, and I stood there, caught between the two worlds, unsure which expectation to meet.
